title: How do formal and informal documents differ? - Quora

response.answer_text: They don't really. Not in North America anyway, where it's allowed to sew you for breathing wrong and having breakfast.  A formal document is conforming and witnessed. Ideally it's worded like a piece of art and it sounds impressive.  Lawyers worth their stuff get a kick out of this. But it's possible to draft a " formal " document on a piece of scrap paper, if it is witnessed and given credence by such a witness. Hoe does it/ they differ?  The more complicated, the better. The more anchored in expectation and labyrinthine wording, the better.  But in the end... It's about how serious the intent is.  A document, a letter, a note... They become  'formal' when witnessed and thus acknowledged.
Formal documents are written following certain conventions and standards, whereas informal documents are more conversational and casual.
